turns.raw_header: You used the tag `!<q>` before your message. I don’t have built‑in knowledge of that specific syntax, but it looks like a custom or tool-specific command—possibly meaning “quote,” “question,” or a formatting directive.
turns.body:
Your content after it is just:

> test

If you’re experimenting, everything is working: I can see and respond to your message normally.
turns.footer: If `!<q>` is meant to trigger a special behavior (e.g., treat the text as a quote, run a query, etc.), tell me what you intend it to do, and I’ll adapt my responses accordingly.

parsed_footer.raw: If `!<q>` is meant to trigger a special behavior (e.g., treat the text as a quote, run a query, etc.), tell me what you intend it to do, and I’ll adapt my responses accordingly.

turns.raw_header: You used `!<o>` this time, followed by:
turns.body:
> second test

I don’t have a predefined behavior for `!<o>` either—it looks like another custom tag (maybe “output,” “option,” or similar). Functionally, I can still just read and respond to the text that follows it.
turns.footer: If you’re testing a system that wraps messages with tags like `!<q>` and `!<o>`, tell me what each tag is supposed to mean, and I can treat messages differently based on the tag (e.g., answer style, format, or role).

parsed_footer.raw: If you’re testing a system that wraps messages with tags like `!<q>` and `!<o>`, tell me what each tag is supposed to mean, and I can treat messages differently based on the tag (e.g., answer style, format, or role).
